location: London. An ante-chamber in the palace.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Good morrow, and well met. How have ye done Since last we saw in France?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: I thank your grace, Healthful; and ever since a fresh admirer Of what I saw there.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: An untimely ague Stay'd me a prisoner in my chamber when Those suns of glory, those two lights of men, Met in the vale of Andren.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: 'Twixt Guynes and Arde: I was then present, saw them salute on horseback; Beheld them, when they lighted, how they clung In their embracement, as they grew together; Which had they, what four throned ones could have weigh'd Such a compounded one?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: All the whole time I was my chamber's prisoner.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Then you lost The view of earthly glory: men might say, Till this time pomp was single, but now married To one above itself. Each following day Became the next day's master, till the last Made former wonders its. To-day the French, All clinquant, all in gold, like heathen gods, Shone down the English; and, to-morrow, they Made Britain India: every man that stood Show'd like a mine. Their dwarfish pages were As cherubins, all guilt: the madams too, Not used to toil, did almost sweat to bear The pride upon them, that their very labour Was to them as a painting: now this masque Was cried incomparable; and the ensuing night Made it a fool and beggar. The two kings, Equal in lustre, were now best, now worst, As presence did present them; him in eye, Still him in praise: and, being present both 'Twas said they saw but one; and no discerner Durst wag his tongue in censure. When these suns-- For so they phrase 'em--by their heralds challenged The noble spirits to arms, they did perform Beyond thought's compass; that former fabulous story, Being now seen possible enough, got credit, That Bevis was believed.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: O, you go far.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: As I belong to worship and affect In honour honesty, the tract of every thing Would by a good discourser lose some life, Which action's self was tongue to. All was royal; To the disposing of it nought rebell'd. Order gave each thing view; the office did Distinctly his full function.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Who did guide, I mean, who set the body and the limbs Of this great sport together, as you guess?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: One, certes, that promises no element In such a business.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I pray you, who, my lord?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: All this was order'd by the good discretion Of the right reverend Cardinal of York.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: The devil speed him! no man's pie is freed From his ambitious finger. What had he To do in these fierce vanities? I wonder That such a keech can with his very bulk Take up the rays o' the beneficial sun And keep it from the earth.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Surely, sir, There's in him stuff that puts him to these ends; For, being not propp'd by ancestry, whose grace Chalks successors their way, nor call'd upon For high feats done to the crown; neither allied For eminent assistants; but, spider-like, Out of his self-drawing web, he gives us note, The force of his own merit makes his way A gift that heaven gives for him, which buys A place next to the king.

lines.speaker: abergavenny
lines.text: I cannot tell What heaven hath given him,--let some graver eye Pierce into that; but I can see his pride Peep through each part of him: whence has he that, If not from hell? the devil is a niggard, Or has given all before, and he begins A new hell in himself.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Why the devil, Upon this French going out, took he upon him, Without the privity o' the king, to appoint Who should attend on him? He makes up the file Of all the gentry; for the most part such To whom as great a charge as little honour He meant to lay upon: and his own letter, The honourable board of council out, Must fetch him in the papers.

lines.speaker: abergavenny
lines.text: I do know Kinsmen of mine, three at the least, that have By this so sickened their estates, that never They shall abound as formerly.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: O, many Have broke their backs with laying manors on 'em For this great journey. What did this vanity But minister communication of A most poor issue?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Grievingly I think, The peace between the French and us not values The cost that did conclude it.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Every man, After the hideous storm that follow'd, was A thing inspired; and, not consulting, broke Into a general prophecy; That this tempest, Dashing the garment of this peace, aboded The sudden breach on't.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Which is budded out; For France hath flaw'd the league, and hath attach'd Our merchants' goods at Bourdeaux.

lines.speaker: abergavenny
lines.text: Is it therefore The ambassador is silenced?

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Marry, is't.

lines.speaker: abergavenny
lines.text: A proper title of a peace; and purchased At a superfluous rate!

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Why, all this business Our reverend cardinal carried.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Like it your grace, The state takes notice of the private difference Betwixt you and the cardinal. I advise you-- And take it from a heart that wishes towards you Honour and plenteous safety--that you read The cardinal's malice and his potency Together; to consider further that What his high hatred would effect wants not A minister in his power. You know his nature, That he's revengeful, and I know his sword Hath a sharp edge: it's long and, 't may be said, It reaches far, and where 'twill not extend, Thither he darts it. Bosom up my counsel, You'll find it wholesome. Lo, where comes that rock That I advise your shunning.

Enter CARDINAL WOLSEY, the purse borne before him,  certain of the Guard, and two Secretaries with  papers. CARDINAL WOLSEY in his passage fixeth his  eye on BUCKINGHAM, and BUCKINGHAM on him, both full of disdain

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: The Duke of Buckingham's surveyor, ha? Where's his examination?

lines.speaker: first secretary
lines.text: Here, so please you.

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Is he in person ready?

lines.speaker: first secretary
lines.text: Ay, please your grace.

lines.speaker: cardinal wolsey
lines.text: Well, we shall then know more; and Buckingham Shall lessen this big look.
Exeunt CARDINAL WOLSEY and his Train

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: This butcher's cur is venom-mouth'd, and I Have not the power to muzzle him; therefore best Not wake him in his slumber. A beggar's book Outworths a noble's blood.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: What, are you chafed? Ask God for temperance; that's the appliance only Which your disease requires.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I read in's looks Matter against me; and his eye reviled Me, as his abject object: at this instant He bores me with some trick: he's gone to the king; I'll follow and outstare him.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Stay, my lord, And let your reason with your choler question What 'tis you go about: to climb steep hills Requires slow pace at first: anger is like A full-hot horse, who being allow'd his way, Self-mettle tires him. Not a man in England Can advise me like you: be to yourself As you would to your friend.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I'll to the king; And from a mouth of honour quite cry down This Ipswich fellow's insolence; or proclaim There's difference in no persons.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Be advised; Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot That it do singe yourself: we may outrun, By violent swiftness, that which we run at, And lose by over-running. Know you not, The fire that mounts the liquor til run o'er, In seeming to augment it wastes it? Be advised: I say again, there is no English soul More stronger to direct you than yourself, If with the sap of reason you would quench, Or but allay, the fire of passion.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Sir, I am thankful to you; and I'll go along By your prescription: but this top-proud fellow, Whom from the flow of gall I name not but From sincere motions, by intelligence, And proofs as clear as founts in July when We see each grain of gravel, I do know To be corrupt and treasonous.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Say not 'treasonous.'

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: To the king I'll say't; and make my vouch as strong As shore of rock. Attend. This holy fox, Or wolf, or both,--for he is equal ravenous As he is subtle, and as prone to mischief As able to perform't; his mind and place Infecting one another, yea, reciprocally-- Only to show his pomp as well in France As here at home, suggests the king our master To this last costly treaty, the interview, That swallow'd so much treasure, and like a glass Did break i' the rinsing.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: Faith, and so it did.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Pray, give me favour, sir. This cunning cardinal The articles o' the combination drew As himself pleased; and they were ratified As he cried 'Thus let be': to as much end As give a crutch to the dead: but our count-cardinal Has done this, and 'tis well; for worthy Wolsey, Who cannot err, he did it. Now this follows,-- Which, as I take it, is a kind of puppy To the old dam, treason,--Charles the emperor, Under pretence to see the queen his aunt-- For 'twas indeed his colour, but he came To whisper Wolsey,--here makes visitation: His fears were, that the interview betwixt England and France might, through their amity, Breed him some prejudice; for from this league Peep'd harms that menaced him: he privily Deals with our cardinal; and, as I trow,-- Which I do well; for I am sure the emperor Paid ere he promised; whereby his suit was granted Ere it was ask'd; but when the way was made, And paved with gold, the emperor thus desired, That he would please to alter the king's course, And break the foresaid peace. Let the king know, As soon he shall by me, that thus the cardinal Does buy and sell his honour as he pleases, And for his own advantage.

lines.speaker: norfolk
lines.text: I am sorry To hear this of him; and could wish he were Something mistaken in't.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: No, not a syllable: I  do pronounce him in that very shape He shall appear in proof.
Enter BRANDON, a Sergeant-at-arms before him, and two or three of the Guard

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: Your office, sergeant; execute it.

lines.speaker: sergeant
lines.text: Sir, My lord the Duke of Buckingham, and Earl Of Hereford, Stafford, and Northampton, I Arrest thee of high treason, in the name Of our most sovereign king.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: Lo, you, my lord, The net has fall'n upon me! I shall perish Under device and practise.

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: I am sorry To see you ta'en from liberty, to look on The business present: 'tis his highness' pleasure You shall to the Tower.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: It will help me nothing To plead mine innocence; for that dye is on me Which makes my whitest part black. The will of heaven Be done in this and all things! I obey. O my Lord Abergavenny, fare you well!

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: Nay, he must bear you company. The king Is pleased you shall to the Tower, till you know How he determines further.
To ABERGAVENNY

lines.speaker: abergavenny
lines.text: As the duke said, The will of heaven be done, and the king's pleasure By me obey'd!

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: Here is a warrant from The king to attach Lord Montacute; and the bodies Of the duke's confessor, John de la Car, One Gilbert Peck, his chancellor--

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: So, so; These are the limbs o' the plot: no more, I hope.

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: A monk o' the Chartreux.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: O, Nicholas Hopkins?

lines.speaker: brandon
lines.text: He.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: My surveyor is false; the o'er-great cardinal Hath show'd him gold; my life is spann'd already: I am the shadow of poor Buckingham, Whose figure even this instant cloud puts on, By darkening my clear sun. My lord, farewell.
Exeunt
